title: update benchmark_longformer with default test suite
body:
**Description**: 
Update benchmark_longformer tool to reduce manual work:
(1) Add a default test suites: memory, latency and parity tests on longformer-base-4096. It will trigger when user does not input any parameter.
(2) Replace --models by --model: only test one model in a run.
(3) Memory test returns the delta of memory (memory_in_test - memory_before_test).

- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

title: Enable more unit tests for ROCM EP
Copy forward signature from PyTorch model.
body:
The original PyTorch `forward` method has some defined input parameters, for example, parameters a, b, c: `def forward(self, a, b, c)`.
But ORTModule's `forward` method defined as `def forward(self, *inputs, **kwargs)`.

The user code may inspect the `forward` signature.
Specifically, Hugginface's data loader uses the signature to decide which data is actually needed.

One aspects of the issue, is that different ORTModule instances can exist at the same time and have different `forward` signatures.

This PR solves the described problem by dynamically creating `_forward` function, binding that dynamically created function to the ORTModule's  `forward`  method, and copying the signature of the original model's `forward` using `functools.update_wrapper`.

title: How can I deploy, a model with ATen-based custom op, with c++ api
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'm trying to deploy a python model, namely [yolact++](https://github.com/dbolya/yolact), 
which includes a DCNv2 module from https://github.com/charlesshang/DCNv2.
This module was implemented with some ATen/THCuda c++ calls.
(BTW, I replaced it with a version from https://github.com/lbin/DCNv2 for later pytorch version.)

To export custom ops into models, I found some related topics:

Firstly, some online materials pointed out that they exported it and registered it with a static `symbolic` function, 
or a call to register_custom_op_symbolic , then they deployed them through ORT python api.
I tried both of them, the models exported appeared fine in Netron, despite including a DCNv2 op in it.
But when deploying models in c++ api, an exception occurred with following message:

```plain
terminated called after throwing an instance of 'Ort::Exception':
  what(): Load model from yolact_plus.onnx failed:Fatal error: DCNv2 is not a registered function/op
```

It seemed that registering in python was not enough for c++ api.

Secondly, I read articles at https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/how-to/add-custom-op.html and https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/how-to/export-pytorch-model.html#export-pytorch-model-with-custom-onnx-operators,
both of which required a new implementation.
I found that values should be attained from a `OrtKernelContent*` in forms of `T*`,
but I don't know how to migrate from ATen methods into an ORT-style implementation.

**System information**
- ONNX Runtime version (you are using): 1.6.0

**Describe the solution you'd like**
**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Maybe one of the following will help me out:
- a way to bridge from an ATen custom op to a c++ custom op.
- a way to register and use an ATen custom op in c++ api.
- an ORT-style c++ implementation for DCNv2.

**Additional context**
In case it should work and I might have made mistakes, please correct my steps.

title: Memcopy (Host->Device) very slow on TX2 with Jetpack 4.5

labels.name: ep:CUDA
labels.description: issues related to the CUDA execution provider

labels.name: platform:jetson
labels.description: issues related to the NVIDIA Jetson platform

body:
**Describe the bug**
A memcopy from CPU to GPU that apparently has to be done takes 1.44 seconds, where the total inference time for the computation is 1.60 seconds. This issue occurs on a Jetson TX2 with Jetpack 4.5 (Cuda 10.2, cuDNN 8.0), but does not take place on a Jetson TX2 with Jetpack 4.2.1 (Cuda 10.0, cuDNN 7.5.0): there the same memcopy only takes 50ms. This duration grows proportional to the batch size of the input.

This seems to be a bug in ONNXRuntime with newer CUDA/cuDNN versions.

I'm not sure what is being copied to GPU btw, or how to figure this out. I converted the model from Tensorflow 2.3 using tf2onnx.convert, and first copied the two inputs to the model to GPU using io_binding(), but this makes no difference in inference time, so I guess it's not the input that's being copied from CPU to GPU. If someone could explain how I do figure this out (and prevent it from happening if possible), that would also be much appreciated.

**Urgency**
None

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Ubuntu 18.04.5 LTS on Jetpack 4.5
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): from source
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.7.0 (without TensorRT bindings)
- Python version: 3.6.9
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): 7.5.0
- CUDA/cuDNN version: CUDA 10.2.89 cuDNN 8.0.0.180
- GPU model and memory: Jetson TX2 8GB

**To Reproduce**
Run attached onnx.py on Jetpack 4.5 to reproduce issue.

onnxruntime_perf_test -e cuda -I ~/onnx/model.onnx -r 10 -t 10 also works, but because that batch size is set to 1, the issue is less clear.

**Expected behavior**
You would expect the memcopy to be not slower than on older Jetpack (CUDA/cuDNN) versions

**Additional attachments**
Attached a trace from both Jetpack 4.2.1 and Jetpack 4.5, the verbose log from Jetpack 4.5, the tf2onnx conversion log and the files to reproduce those traces.
[github issue.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6029316/github.issue.zip)

**Additional context**
The Tensorflow model is from https://github.com/alleveenstra/attentionocr where I removed the positional embedding generation using tf.eye because tf2onnx does not support this.

title: Support nested sequence and mapping types in ORTModule
body:
**Description**: Support for nested sequences and mappings as output types as defined by users in ORTModule.

Changes in this pull request will enable users to return more complex types in the forward method of their ```torch.nn.Module``` such as nested dictionaries and nested sequences.

The solution can be summarized with these points:
- The ```ORTModule``` saves a new attribute called ```_flattened_output_module``` which is another ```torch.nn.Module``` called ```FlattenedOutputModule``` which is responsible for transforming the output of the original module (which can be a complex structure) to a flat tuple structure.
- Since, the exporter understands the flat tuple structure, exporting this ```_flattened_output_module``` to an onnx model does not lead to any errors.
- Before returning the output to the user, the output (from the backend) needs to be unflattened back to the original structure (that the user is expecting).
  - To address this, a schema of the output is saved called ```_original_module_output_schema```.
  - This schema represents the original output where all ```torch.Tensor```s are replaced with a ```_TensorStrub``` object so as to avoid holding on to memory that was needed by the ```torch.Tensor```.
  - This schema is used to unflatten the output from the backend (which is obtained as a flattened tuple) into the output structure that is expected by the user by replacing all ```_TensorStub```s with the values from the output tuple.

This pull request adds a new file ```_ortmodule_output_transformation.py``` that is responsible for all the output parsing and transformations. In addition to the above work, a few unit tests are also added that validate the support for complex return types.

title: Onnxruntime fails to load a session (Operator not implemented)
body:
Hi,

Due to some reason I am using and older version of onnxruntime (1.1.2), which I believe supports onnx version 1.6 and opset version 11. I have an alexnet model from onnx model zoo ([AlexNet-3](https://github.com/onnx/models/blob/master/vision/classification/alexnet/model/bvlcalexnet-3.onnx)) which has ir_version 3 and opset version also 3. But InferenceSession fails to create a session for this model with the following error - 
```python
---> 43         self._sess.load_model(providers)
     44 
     45         self._session_options = self._sess.session_options

NotImplemented: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 9 : NOT_IMPLEMENTED : Could not find an implementation for the node Relu(1)

Since cuDNN supports ConvolutionBackward with up to 5 dimensions, we can support 3D ConvTranspose by simply removing the check which raises an error if the input has 5 dimensions.

Fixes #6703

title: Fix regression in constant folding optimizer
body:
**Description**: #5457 added an enhancement to constant folding optimizer where-in dangling input nodes feeding into a node that is constant folded will be removed. It used a node iterator to iterate through all input nodes while removing the input nodes along the way. The problem is that on removal of the corresponding input node, its iterator is invalidated. This change fixes the issue and adds a test case to cover the change.


**Motivation and Context**
Fix regression from 1.6.0

title: Update transformers benchmark for transformers 4.3.* and ORT 1.7
body:
**Description**: 
(1) Fix GPT-2 ONNX conversion for transformers 4.3.*.
(2) Update benchmark for ORT 1.7.0: remove openmp related code in benchmark
(3) Refine the list of pretrained models for benchmark.

**Motivation and Context**
- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

Transformers 4.3.* has a breaking change: past key values are two tensors instead of one. That causes GPT-2 onnx conversion failure.

Old benchmark assumes that CPU package has openmp. Since openmp is removed in ORT 1.7, we remove openmp related settings in official benchmark correspondingly.

Some pretrained model like T5 will fail in onnx conversion. Disable them in the list, and will address them later. Also remove some "near duplicated" or "not popular" models.

title: Move create kernels earlier during session init
body:
This change split the kernel initialization logic into two part, the constructor and a virtual function SecondaryInit(). The goal here is to move the create kernel phase earlier, at least before const tensor de-serialization, and for some kernel init logic that depend on weight tensor values, those are moved to SecondaryInit()

**Motivation and Context**
*Problem*:

Some kernels prepack some const input tensors (weights) into another buffer, maintained internally in the kernel. After prepacking, the const tensor should be deleted, with its memory buffer reclaimed. 

Unfortunately, this leads to large amount of wasted memory in most cases, as these buffers are allocated either on memory pattern, or on memory arena, which makes deallocation impossible.

*Solution*:

We need to make the memory pattern planner aware of the prepacking, so that it won't trace const tensors that are going to be prepacked and deleted. Unfortunately this can not be done in a jiffy, as only the kernel object would know whether a weight tensor should be prepacked or not. But the memory pattern planner is run before the kernel objects are created.

So this change is the first step of implementing the solution: we move the kernel creation earlier, before memory pattern planner  runs. In the future we will have other changes for rest of the work.

title: [OpenVINO-EP] Find package changes
body:
**Description:** 
uses Find package() for configuring OpenVINO Provider CMake settings.

**Motivation and Context:**

title: Fix app packaging in UWP
body:
**Description**: Workaround for #6249

**Motivation and Context**
Nuget supports multi-plarform/multi-architecture packages and Nuget/msbuild picks the correct DLLs from `runtimes\` if you follow their naming conventions ([available here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/supporting-multiple-target-frameworks#architecture-specific-folders)). But at some point it started copying files from `native` into UAP builds, causing #6249. I'm not sure if this is a bug in msbuild or our understanding of "native" is incorrect (maybe "native" means supported everywhere, and we should use another moniker for non-UWP? [The reference of existing monikers is here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/target-frameworks#supported-frameworks)).

Anyways, `csharp/src/Microsoft.AI.MachineLearning/Microsoft.AI.MachineLearning.targets` already handles the logic to choose which DLLs to copy so we should do fine if Nuget doesn't interfere. This PR stops Nuget from messing with our packaging. There isn't a straightforward way to tell Nuget to stop doing it (see [discussion](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/329) and [discussion](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/452) - [the](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5986#issuecomment-732401471) [supported](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#controlling-dependency-assets) [way](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec#specifying-files-to-include-in-the-package) is adding some tags to PackageReference, which means the **consumers** of the Nuget package would have to add a couple of lines to their project), so my proposed workaround is simply renaming the native folder so Nuget doesn't attempt to copy DLLs automatically.

Not following the folder naming convention and doing the copying through msbuild targets is also done in other projects (e.g. see [Microsoft's WebView2](https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/WebView2Feedback/issues/461#issuecomment-731551769) and I don't expect it to cause issues.

---

I tested my changes by locally editing a Nuget package and they fix UWP. I seem to have recently lost permission to queue jobs at aiinfra, so I couldn't do a clean run of the YAML job to see if it's actually producing a valid package. Before merging we should run the Nuget packaging pipeline and test if both UWP and Desktop are fine. I'll be out of office for the next few days, so @smk2007 will likely be the one driving this PR.

title: Remove support for strided 64-bit emulation in DML's Cast kernel
body:
**Description**: Removes support for strided 64-bit emulation in DML's Cast kernel.

**Motivation and Context**
A model from one of our partners regressed with a failure to evaluate due to the addition of strided 64-bit emulation in the DML EP for the Cast operator. Specifically, the model uses a Cast from int32 to int64 to produce the input shape to a Reshape node. When supplied with a shape dimension of -1 (int32 0xffffffff), the strided emulation in Cast ends up producing an int64 result of 0x00000000ffffffff. This is then fed into the Reshape operator, where it produces an incorrect tensor shape and a failure during evaluation.

Generally speaking we assume that using strided 64-bit emulation is safe if a node's inputs came from the DML EP itself. This isn't true in the general case for Cast, however - casting negative signed values can and will produce incorrect outputs with strided emulation.

After this change, Cast nodes with 64-bit types will fall back to CPU unless running on a GPU that native supports 64-bit datatypes.

title: Update Attention and QAttention to support pruned model
body:
**Description**: 
Update attention operator to support hidden dimension pruning, like reducing number of attention heads through Q, K and V Linear layer.

Change of shape for input and stacked weights for Q, K and K are like the following.

Before:
* input shape (batch_size, sequence_length, **hidden_size**)
* weight shape (**hidden_size**, 3*hidden_size)

After:
* input shape (batch_size, sequence_length, **input_hidden_size**)
* weight shape (**input_hidden_size**, 3*hidden_size)

The input_hidden_size and hidden_size can have different values.

Note: Updated some test models for EmbedLayerNormFusion to fix invalid Attention weights to get build passed.

**Motivation and Context**
- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

Transformer model pruning becomes popular since it could improve latency significantly with acceptable loss in relevance.

Current attention operator assumes that hidden size does not change in Linear (Fully Connection) for Q, K and V.  When some attention heads are pruned, current attention operator cannot be applied.

title: Release buffers for prepacked tensors
body:
**Description**:

Enable initializer tensor allocator to transfer buffer ownership to Tensors, so that these buffers can be released after these initializers are prepacked. 

**Motivation and Context**

Prepacking is a kind of operation, where some kernels pre-process weight tensors into another form, in order to speed up inferencing. Prepacking often results in a bigger blob. So kernels usually store the prepacking results into other memory buffers. After prepacking, the original tensors should be deleted to save memory.

Currently, even after these weight tensors are deleted, their memory buffers are not released, resulting in memory waste. This change try to release these buffers when it is possible. There are two implementations of tensor allocators: 1) mem pattern planner based allocator tries to allocate all initializers on a single buffer. It's very hard to release individual tensor buffers in this case. 2) simple tensor allocator allocates each tensors individually. However, it does not give ownership of the buffer to the tensor, so we can not release the buffer either.

This change focus on 2) above. In simple tensor allocators, we tries to give up buffer ownership, and transfer it to the tensor.

TODO about mem pattern planner based allocator, do we have to trace all the initializers? Can we only trace those that needs to be allocated continuously (currently only inputs to nccl kernels, it seems), and let the simple tensor allocators handle the rest?

title: Disable Materializing Grads
body:
Disable materializing grads in forward so that None object will not be converted to a tensor filled with zeros prior to calling backward. We will materialize the output grads by ourselves. If the output grad is None when calling backward, when it's the direct input of backward graph, we will materialize it to all-0 tensor with same shape of output, otherwise, we will use the scalar-0 tensor, because in this case there will be Add node added, and the scalar-0 tensor is always OK as one of inputs of the Add node.

This PR also contains a fix for module gradient builder. With the fix, we will not ignore any output grads from PT, if it's output of one node, we will add an Add node to add the node output with the grad tensor from PT.

Take the BERT large as example, change the user outputs to return all of loss, prediction_scores and seq_relationship_score, but call the backward from loss only. Without set_materialize_grads(False), the max batch size is 80 (on 32G V100), when set to False, the max batch size can reach to 88. Python debugger also confirms that when set to False, the output grads for prediction_scores and seq_relationship_score are None instead of all-zero tensors.

hey, I've exported the huggingface's T5 model to onnx, using `torch.onnx.export() ` and ran it on onnxruntime with the following optimization.

```

the converted t5 onnx model runs 2-2.5 times faster than the PyTorch model for smaller sequence length under (100 tokens) and beam num (<3). 

however, the onnx model runs slower than the PyTorch model for longer sequence length and higher beam-search number.
what might be causing the model to slow down? is it just the t5 model or do all transformer onnx models perform poorly on large batch size and sequence length?

any suggestions on improving the model speed would be appreciated.

title: Enable priority-based execution order as default to support inputs with symbolic/dynamic shape
body:
**Description**: When building training graph without concrete shape, e.g. bert, the max bs would be 20, far less than 35 when providing concrete shape. The reason is because memory allocation planner can't efficiently assign reusable buffers due to symbolic shapes happening in later stage of execution order.
The solution is to enable priority-based execution order (for Shape op), thus memory allocation can be better planned. During the experiment, the max bs can now be 36.  

In this PR:
- introduce new flag - "_use_static_shape" in case we want to expose it to user
- fixed gradient builder issues when testing gpt-2 and bert related UTs
- encounter CUDA error with gpt-2 (regression by merging code from master) - thus has dependency on https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/6833 and https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/6838 - both are merged

title: Change OpKernel class to be shared with shared providers
body:
In the previous shared providers there aren't many OpKernel classes, and the existing Provider_OpKernel wrapper was fine. With the opposibility of making Cuda a shared provider, having this need to be changed per OpKernel adds a lot of complexity.

It was fairly straightforward to make OpKernel work with shared providers with minimal changes.

In this change, the ONNX_OPERATOR_* macros can also be shared with the shared providers.

**Description**: As titled.

**Motivation and Context**
- During megatron transformations, MegatronF is created and should put before MatMul for q/k/v of the attention layers. While currently, we update all consumers of MatMul's input op, no matter it is MatMul or not. This is incorrect. In forward pass, this is fine, but in BP graph, MegatronF will be mapped to AllReduce, we will see results diff compared with correct runs.

title: Collective ops orders - For Feedbacks

labels.name: training
labels.description: issues related to ONNX Runtime training; typically submitted using template

body:
**Description**: Describe your changes.

**Motivation and Context**

We will see there are some mismatch in the 68 and 279 attention bp all reduce operations. Be noted: 279 and 68 can be run in parallel (from the view of graph) since they are in different branches, they don’t take dependency on each other. 
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10530022/109476794-44aeb600-7ab2-11eb-9535-0ce745f0c041.png)

here is a solution: 
A). When we build the forward and backward graph, we give each collective ops a unique and auto incremental id as an attribute. All id is assigned in the same order on all ranks, this is guaranteed so far by our code. 
B). All collective ops having bigger id will take dependency on all smaller ids, when doing topo sort (and execution planning).
In this way, all ranks will share the same global order for collective ops. 

This change is a first step for implementing all those, before going forward, I want to collect some feedbacks, in case of any useless efforts.

title: Refine force CPU fallback logic in the CUDA EP
body:
**Description**: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/4940 refined the force fallback to CPU logic for Shape based subgraphs from its initial version. A crude overview of the previous logic to determine if a node needs to be forced to run on CPU was if all its inputs were either on CPU (unless the corresponding CUDA kernel for the op explicitly required the inputs on CPU) or were initializers. The refinement added was to check if the initializers were "small" ( < 100 elements) and if there was only one consumer of this initializer (which is the current node itself). The single consumer logic is overly strict and will cause very poor perf in "repeated shape subgraph pattern" scenarios. 

Example:

Consider many such repeating subgraphs (common in sequence based models)
                                                                                       
-> Shape -> Gather (2 indices) -> Concat (1 element) -> Reshape  <- (data to be reshaped)

With the new logic this becomes

-> Shape -> MemCpyFromHost -> Gather -> Concat -> MemCpyToHost -> Reshape  <- (data to be reshaped)

It places the `Gather` and `Concat` nodes on CUDA because they use initializers shared between all Gathers and Concats in subgraphs processing each sequence index. Since Shape's output is on CPU and finally Reshape's shape info is required on CPU, this tiny subgraph now needs 2 device-host copies + 2 CUDA kernel launches (overkill for gathering 2 shape indices and concating one element to its result) and what is worse is that this is repeated multiple times.

This change relaxes the constraint that the initializer for a candidate node needs to have only one consumer (there is no real case for having this strict check AFAIK).

This may improve perf of sequence models with a lot of shape processing subgraphs.

**Motivation and Context**
Significantly improves the perf of a 1PP model. Saves hundreds of memcpys and overheads of unnecessary CUDA kernel launches and improves perf by >30%

title: Ability to fuse non-square (pruned) attention weights for BERT-like models
body:
Following @tianleiwu implementation [for non squared (i.e. pruned) attention layer](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/pull/6819) this PR introduces the necessary machinery to fuse Attention layer when optimizing BERT model through `onnxruntime_tools` optimizer.

 What does this PR does: 

1. Do no assume squared matrices of shape `(self.hidden_size, self.hidden_size)` for QKV weights
2. Split up weights shape into a more generic `in_size` & `out_size` mapping -respectively- the incoming number of features and the projected number of features for the matmul operator.
3. Infer the hidden size representation for each individual head in order to correctly infer the **dynamic** number of heads in each Attention layer. 
4. Correctly specify the `num_heads` meta attribute according point 3.

title: [optimization, quantization, inference] Clarification regarding docs/API

labels.name: core runtime
labels.description: issues related to core runtime

body:
Hi,

I have a BERT model exported from PyTorch as ONNX and then optimized & quantized with `onnxruntime_tools`. All of this is performed in offline manner, on the same machine. Next, the resulting model is served for predictions with `onnxruntime` and `CPUExecutionProvider`, on different machines. Here are the relevant code snippets:

- export to ONNX, optimization and quantization (same machine):
```python
import torch
from onnxruntime.quantization import QuantType, quantize_dynamic
from onnxruntime_tools import optimizer
from onnxruntime_tools.transformers.onnx_model_bert import BertOptimizationOptions

# loading weights into `model` variable omitted for brevity

with torch.no_grad():
    inputs = {
        "input_ids": torch.ones(1, 128, dtype=torch.int64),
        "attention_mask": torch.ones(1, 128, dtype=torch.int64),
        "token_type_ids": torch.ones(1, 128, dtype=torch.int64),
    }
    outputs = model(**inputs)
symbolic_names = {0: "batch_size", 1: "max_seq_len"}
torch.onnx.export(
    model=model,
    args=(inputs["input_ids"], inputs["attention_mask"], inputs["token_type_ids"]),
    f="model.onnx",
    opset_version=12,
    do_constant_folding=True,
    input_names=["input_ids", "attention_mask", "token_type_ids"],
    output_names=["output"],
    dynamic_axes={
        "input_ids": symbolic_names,
        "attention_mask": symbolic_names,
        "token_type_ids": symbolic_names,
    },
)

opt_options = BertOptimizationOptions("bert")
opt_options.enable_embed_layer_norm = False
opt_model = optimizer.optimize_model(
    input="model.onnx",
    model_type="bert",
    num_heads=12,
    hidden_size=768,
    optimization_options=opt_options,
)
opt_model.save_model_to_file("model_opt")

quantize_dynamic(
    model_input="model_opt",
    model_output="model_opt_quant",
    weight_type=QuantType.QInt8,
)
```

- serving for predictions (different machines):
```python
from onnxruntime import GraphOptimizationLevel, InferenceSession, SessionOptions

options = SessionOptions()
options.graph_optimization_level = GraphOptimizationLevel.ORT_ENABLE_ALL
ort_session = InferenceSession(
	path_or_bytes="model_opt_quant",
	sess_options=options,
	providers=["CPUExecutionProvider"],
)
```

- versions of packages being used:
```
torch==1.6.0
onnxruntime==1.6.0
onnxruntime-tools==1.6.0
```

What I've been noticing recently is that on _some_ machines (equipped only with CPUs - there are no GPUs involved at optimization/quantization/inference stages), I get _slightly_ different metrics (precision/recall/f1) - despite the fact that each one of them has the same model, the same code that serves it and that I perform evaluation with the same dataset. So the only variable here is the hardware - which makes sense, considering that [your documentation][1] states the following:

> When running in offline mode, make sure to use the exact same options (e.g., execution providers, optimization level) and hardware as the target machine that the model inference will run on (e.g., you cannot run a model pre-optimized for a GPU execution provider on a machine that is equipped only with CPU).
>
> When layout optimizations are enabled, the offline mode can only be used on compatible hardware to the environment when the offline model is saved. For example, if model has layout optimized for AVX2, the offline model would require CPUs that support AVX2.

Moreover, I'm aware of [this readme][2], which states that quantization and graph optimization may not always work together.

But there are couple of things which are still a bit unclear to me:
- Which optimization options really matter when you write "make sure to use the exact same options"? You mention execution providers and optimization level - but how about things like e.g. `BertOptimizationOptions`, which doesn't have their counterparts in `SessionOptions`?
- What is the expected outcome of having `opt_level=0` during offline optimization and `ORT_ENABLE_ALL` during inference session, with quantization between them (i.e. as in the code snippets above)? How about having `opt_level=99` and `ORT_ENABLE_ALL` instead? 
- If I don't get any errors or warnings from `quantize_dynamic`, is it OK to assume that the current combination of graph optimization and quantization settings works OK?
- If I don't get any errors or warnings at the serving stage (i.e. from `InferenceSession`), is it OK to assume that everything _should_ work fine (i.e. my metrics should be the same on every machine)?
- Finally, [the docstring for `InferenceSession`][3] mentions ORT and ONNX formats - what is the difference between them?

Thanks in advance for shedding some light on the questions above.

[1]: https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/resources/graph-optimizations.html#onlineoffline-mode
[2]: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/onnxruntime/python/tools/quantization/README.md#quantization-and-graph-optimization
[3]: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/d761571afcbc50be94b2ffdfcaa09cfd9e2eaf5e/onnxruntime/python/onnxruntime_inference_collection.py#L238

Hello,

Inference on MacOS with models containing respectively a QLinearConv and a QLinearMatMul gives an error. The same models are okay on Windows and Ubuntu (attached below). This is from the CI (running on github actions) of a Pytorch quantization-aware training library I maintain, so I don't have access to a real system unfortunately.

**Urgency**
No urgency.

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): macos-latest on github actions (not sure which version that is)
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): installed from pip
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.6.0
- Python version: tested with 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8
- Visual Studio version (if applicable):
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source):
- CUDA/cuDNN version: cpu only
- GPU model and memory:

**To Reproduce**
- You can find my CI runs here https://github.com/Xilinx/brevitas/runs/2004964504?check_suite_focus=true . I use nox (a python tox-like library) to wrap tasks and execute them in a virtualenv. The two failing .onnx files are attached, I generated them locally running the same task on my Windows laptop (where it doesn't fail).
[qlinear_layers.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6062798/qlinear_layers.zip)



**Expected behavior**
Inference shouldn't fail. 

**Additional context**
The issue with QLinearMatMul arises when the layer is exported from versions of Pytorch >= 1.3.0, so for 1.1.0 and 1.2.0 it works (I'm already suppressing errors for pytorch 1.3.0 to 1.6.0 in my CI, so it doesn't show in the logs reported above). The issue with QLinearConv arises only when the layer is exported from Pytorch 1.7.1 (I'm not testing against 1.7.0 so not sure how it behaves with that) but for Pytorch <= 1.6.0 it works fine. 
When I say export I mean defining a custom symbolic layer in Pytorch that maps to QLinearMatMul/QLinearConv. I understand this is probably not a scenario that is really supported by onnxruntime, but I figured reporting the issue wouldn't hurt. If this is a known limitation I'm happy to mark it as such in my library.

title: same structure with different parameters run at very different speeds
body:
**Describe the bug**
  I have a ssd-vgg style PyTorch model and export it to ONNXs through `torch.onnx.export`. Two onnx models are exported and the difference between them are only the parameters. 
  
  One of the models, whose scales and variances of the BN layers are initialized to 1, and means and bias are initialized to 0, runs about **3ms** in my pc. And the other, whose parameters are resumed from a pre-trained model runs about **15ms** in my pc.
  
So I wonder why there is a large performance gap between these two models. I think this may caused by the parameters of bn layer, because if I change parameters of some BN layers of the pre-trained model to 1 and 0, the model becomes faster.
**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): win10
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): binary
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.6.0 cpu
- Python version: 3.7.10
- CPU: Intel i5-6500 with AVX2 and **OMP_NUM_THREADS** is set to 1
- models: [models.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6068460/models.zip)



**To Reproduce**
```
def run_benchmark_onnx(model_file):
    elapsed = 0
    dummy_data = torch.randn(1, 3, 300, 300).cpu().numpy()
    ort_session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession(model_file)
    ort_inputs = {ort_session.get_inputs()[0].name: dummy_data}
    with torch.no_grad():
        for i in range(200):
            start = time.time()
            onnx_outs = ort_session.run(None, ort_inputs)
            end = time.time()
            elapsed = elapsed + (end-start)
    print('Elapsed time: %3.5f ms' % (elapsed/200.0*1000))
run_benchmark_onnx("slow.onnx")
run_benchmark_onnx("fast.onnx")
```

**Expected behavior**
These two models should  have the same speed performance.

title: Move constants from heap to stack to avoid randomness on cudnn function
body:
Solve a random output issue for cuda models from speech team.
By tests it is clear that when allocating the constants on heap, cudnn functions sometime fail to get the correct value, so moving them to per-thread stack. Another possible reason is that during inferencing, cudnn functions has mutual-exclusion-read-relationship on same memory address, so letting them per-call specific solves the problem.

title: TFlite model crashes in ONNX runtime
body:
**Describe the bug**
I transformed a tflite model to onnx model using tf2onnx. The conversion process went well but when I use the model in python, the program quits without any warnings or errors. At first, I thought there was a problem with the conversion process so I opened an issue here : [](https://github.com/onnx/tensorflow-onnx/issues/1349)

**Urgency**
I am currently trying to deploy the models in our company to production and ONNX runtime seems like the best option for us. So this is rather urgent. If we succeed in deploying our model, we might expand the use of onnx runtime for the rest of our deep learning tasks.

**System information**
- OS : Windows (64 and 32 bits)
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): binary
- ONNX Runtime version: '1.6.0'
- Python version: 3.8.5
- Visual Studio version (if applicable):
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): 
- CUDA/cuDNN version: we're not using GPU for inference
- GPU model and memory: we're not using GPU for inference

**To Reproduce**
This is a sample code for loading the model and making a prediction with it:
```
import numpy as np
import onnx 
from onnx import backend 

import onnxruntime as rt
import os
from PIL import Image
import cv2
import time


path_to_model = 'models/ONNXModels/tflite_model_2.onnx'
path_to_img = "path\\to\\image\\000_d1.png"

model_path = os.path.join(path_to_model)

sess = rt.InferenceSession(model_path)
input_name = sess.get_inputs()[0].name
output_names = []
for output in sess.get_outputs():
   output_names.append(output.name)

print("input_name : ", input_name)
print("output_names : ", output_names)

elapsed_time = 0

for i in range(100):
   
   image = cv2.imread(path_to_img)
   image = cv2.resize(image, (128,32), interpolation=cv2.INTER_CUBIC)
   image = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

   image = np.expand_dims(image, axis=0)
   image = np.expand_dims(image, axis=3)
   #print('image.shape = ', image.shape)

   image = image.astype(np.float32)
   t1 = time.process_time()

   out = sess.run(output_names, {input_name: image})
   t2 = time.process_time()

   elapsed_time += t2 - t1

print(f"process time = {elapsed_time/100} s")
```

The onnx model that was used : 
[tflite_model_2.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6075440/tflite_model_2.zip)


**Expected behavior**
I expected the program to run until the end and give me the elapsed_time.


**Additional context**
The original model that I transformed into a onnx model was a tflite model. The tflite model works fine.

title: python API: onnxruntime.set_seed does not seem to work
body:
**Describe the bug**
I am using the Random* family of onnx nodes and would like to run some reproducible tests

**Urgency**
none

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Windows 10 Build 19042
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): binary
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.6.0
- Python version: 3.8.7
- Visual Studio version (if applicable):
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source):
- CUDA/cuDNN version:
- GPU model and memory:

**To Reproduce**
```python
import numpy
import onnx
import onnxruntime
import onnxruntime.backend as onnxruntime_backend
# import onnxruntime.capi._pybind_state as bind_state

onnxruntime.set_seed(0)

node = onnx.helper.make_node(
    "RandomUniformLike",
    inputs=["x"],
    outputs=["y"],
)

x_value_info = onnx.helper.make_tensor_value_info(
    "x", onnx.TensorProto.FLOAT, [1]
)

y_value_info = onnx.helper.make_tensor_value_info(
    "y", onnx.TensorProto.FLOAT, [1]
)

computation_graph_def = onnx.helper.make_graph(
    [node],
    "test_seed",
    [x_value_info],
    [y_value_info],
)

computation_model_def = onnx.helper.make_model(
    computation_graph_def,
    producer_name="test",
)
computation_model_def.opset_import[0].version = 12

sess = onnxruntime_backend.prepare(computation_model_def, log_severity_level=3, device="CPU")

x = numpy.zeros((1), dtype=numpy.float32)

for __ in range(10):
    y = sess.run(x)
    print(y)
```

Launch the code above several times, the expected results is that the output should be the same every time because we set the seed explicitely. To avoid issues with threading the tensor is a single scalar.

**Expected behavior**
Output should be the same between program runs which is not the case

**Screenshots**
none

**Additional context**

onnx version 1.8.1
numpy version 1.18.5
From onnxruntime_pybind_state.cc:

```cpp
  m.def(
      "set_seed", [](const int64_t seed) { utils::SetRandomSeed(seed); },
      "Sets the seed used for random number generation in Onnxruntime.");
```

title: Revert Gather Grad optimization in PR 6381 targeted for Rocm
body:
For reasons not fully understood, PR 6381 has increased the variance of the observed loss on our BERT convergence test. As it is only an optimization, we will revert for now and revisit the situation in the future.

Commit | Note | Final Loss | Sigma | Max-diff | % noise
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
7f57317 | PR   6381 | 0.674179 | 0.0136674 | 0.02963 | 2.03%
9a9e741 | comment optimization | 0.670375 | 0.00052346 | 0.001588 | 0.08%




Final loss is calculated across 10 runs of run_convergence_test.py.
